prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel has not shown any eagerness to order remand. As a matter of practice, the Panel is unlikely to order remand unless the transferee court has certified the cases ready for trial and, therefore, appropriate for remand. The decisions reflect a preference for actions to remain in the transferee court until they are resolved or to be remanded as a group when all common pretrial proceedings are complete.

The Panel has stated a number of reasons for denying remand. In one early decision the Panel decided that the pendency of a motion before the transferee court to sever a counterclaim and transfer a counterclaim was sufficient to prevent remand.[1] In another case the Panel rejected arguments that two remaining actions should be remanded because of settlement of the balance of the cases originally transferred.[2]

The pendency of a motion in the transferee court has a significantly greater impact in preventing remand than the pendency of a pretrial motion in a potential transferor court would in preventing transfer under the statute.[3] The Panel has repeatedly expressed its reluctance or even unwillingness to remand a case before pretrial proceedings are concluded.[4] The fact that a pretrial motion has been filed in the transferee court and has not been ruled upon makes remand unlikely.[5] If the motion pending in the transferee court relates only to a single action potentially subject to remand or if it relates to issues that the transferee and transferor courts are equally well able to consider, then the motion will not prevent remand.[6]

The Panel has remanded a number of cases to the transferor court for trial following completion of pretrial proceedings in the transferee court. Remand is appropriate where the transferee court has completed and closed discovery and determined that the case is ready for trial.[7] The Panel has also accepted a transferee court's suggestion of remand of a single case where that case was transferred as a tag-along action and coordination of discovery between that case and the previously transferred cases was not efficient or feasible.[8]

The mere fact that pretrial proceedings have been concluded in some or most of the transferred cases does not justify remand of other cases initially transferred by the Panel. Even if the transferee court had disposed of all but one transferred case, the Panel may refuse to remand that single case to the transferor district because discovery still remained to be completed in that case.[9]

The Panel has considered the possibility of remand as a factor in making an initial transfer decision. For example, in an air crash case the Panel rejected arguments that differences in the types and complexity of potentially transferable cases dictated that transfer not be ordered. Instead, the Panel noted that if the group of cases became ready for trial ahead of the remaining cases, they could “be separated and remanded pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a) as soon as pretrial is completed as to them.”[10] The Panel has repeatedly noted this possibility,[11] but it has rarely ordered remand of these subgroups of cases.

The Panel will not conditionally order remand at the time of initial transfer.[12] Although the Panel's decision in that event does not reveal the reason for the request for conditional remand, it is possible that the plaintiff seeking the order wanted to avoid the possibility that the transferee court would transfer the case to itself for all purposes once the Panel had ordered transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[13]
